Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Broadcast address
b. Multicast address
c. IP address
d. MAC address
e. Unicast address
LLM Explanation: Ethernet addresses that can send one frame to be delivered to multiple devices on a LAN are described by broadcast and multicast addresses. A broadcast address allows a frame to be sent to all devices on the LAN, while a multicast address enables sending a frame to a specific group of devices on the LAN. IP address, MAC address, and unicast address do not fit this description as they are used for sending frames to a single specific device.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CD
b. CSMA/CA
c. TCP/IP
d. TCP/UDP
LLM Explanation: CSMA/CD, which stands for Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection, is a set of rules that determines how network devices respond when two devices send data at the same time, resulting in a collision. When a collision is detected, both devices stop transmitting, wait for a random time interval, and then retry to send the data again.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/5234-csma-cd.html']

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard 1000BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling. The '1000' in 1000BASE-T refers to the speed of 1000 Mbps or 1 Gbps. 10BASE-T and 100BASE-T are standards for 10 Mbps and 100 Mbps Ethernet respectively, while option 'd' (1BASE-T) is not a valid Ethernet standard.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 3: Fundamentals of LANs)', 'IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Working Group (https://www.ieee802.org/3/)']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The preamble field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet header allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks. It consists of a 56-bit pattern of alternating 1s and 0s that enables bit synchronization. The preamble is followed by the Start Frame Delimiter (SFD) field, which signals the start of the frame.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/8021x/17053-103.html']

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Source
b. Destination
c. Unicast
d. Broadcast
LLM Explanation: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the destination IP address is in a different subnet than the host. When a host needs to communicate with another device on a different network, it will forward the packets to its default gateway, which is responsible for routing the packets to the appropriate network.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 16: IP Routing', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens, Chapter 2: Link Layer']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol in the TCP/IP model. It is used for sending and receiving email messages between servers. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and IP (Internet Protocol) reside in the transport and network layers, respectively. Ethernet is a protocol used in the data link layer for local area networking.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of TCP/IP Transport and Applications', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) resides in the Transport layer of the TCP/IP architecture. TCP is responsible for reliable, connection-oriented delivery of data segments between applications running on hosts. SMTP operates at the Application layer, Ethernet at the Data Link layer, and IP at the Internet (Network) layer.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 3: Fundamentals of TCP/IP Transport and Applications)', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: The Internet Protocol (IP) resides in the Internet layer of the TCP/IP architecture. IP is responsible for addressing, packaging, and routing functions. The other choices reside in different layers: SMTP in the Application layer, TCP in the Transport layer, and Ethernet in the Network Access layer.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet is a protocol that resides in the Data Link and Physical layers of the TCP/IP architecture. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol, TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a transport layer protocol, and IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer protocol.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. ping
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. DNS
LLM Explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) is used by a device to learn the MAC address associated with an IP address on the same network. When a device needs to send data to another device on the local network, it uses ARP to broadcast a request asking for the MAC address corresponding to the destination IP address. The device with that IP address responds with its MAC address, allowing the sender to encapsulate the data with the correct destination MAC address.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 5: Fundamentals of IPv4 Addressing and Routing', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13718-5.html']

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and PC
b. Switch and PC
c. Hub and switch
d. Router and hub
LLM Explanation: Straight-through Ethernet cables are used to connect devices of different types, such as a router to a PC or a switch to a PC. This is because these devices use different pin assignments on their Ethernet ports (MDI on one end and MDI-X on the other). Conversely, when connecting similar devices, like a hub to a switch or a router to a hub, a crossover cable is required to match the transmit and receive pins properly.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/21223-cable-connection-21223.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. TCP
b. HTTP
c. Ethernet
d. PPP
e. SMTP
f. HTTPS
LLM Explanation: The data-link layer protocols in the TCP/IP model are responsible for delivering data over the physical network links. Ethernet and PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) are two examples of data-link layer protocols. Ethernet is commonly used in local area networks (LANs), while PPP is used for point-to-point connections, such as dial-up or serial links. TCP, HTTP, SMTP, and HTTPS are higher-layer protocols that operate at the transport layer (TCP) and application layer (HTTP, SMTP, HTTPS) of the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols, W. Richard Stevens, Addison-Wesley']

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
c. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
d. Forwarding IP packets based on a packet’s destination IP address
LLM Explanation: The main functions of a routing protocol are to learn routes advertised by neighboring routers and put those routes into the routing table, and to advertise known routes to neighboring routers. Learning routes for directly connected subnets is done by the router itself, not the routing protocol. Forwarding IP packets based on the destination address is a function of the router's forwarding logic, not the routing protocol.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 16: IP Routing Essentials', 'Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Routing and Packet Forwarding']

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When you enter a hostname like www.examsdigest.com in a web browser, the computer does not directly send an IP packet to that hostname. Instead, it first uses the Domain Name System (DNS) to resolve the hostname to its corresponding IP address. DNS is a distributed database that maps domain names to IP addresses. Once the IP address is obtained through DNS resolution, the computer then sends the IP packet to that resolved IP address, which is used by the web server hosting the website for Examsdigest.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of WANs and IP Routing', 'RFC 1034: Domain Names - Concepts and Facilities', 'RFC 1035: Domain Names - Implementation and Specification']

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Multicast
c. Unicast
d. MAC
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to send data to every node on a local network segment. It allows a single transmission to reach all devices rather than sending to each one individually (unicast) or to a specific subset of devices (multicast). The broadcast address is a special form of the network or subnet address with the host portion set to all binary ones.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 13: Broadcast and Multicast Traffic', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. UDP
b. HTTP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is the correct answer. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP are the two most commonly used transport layer protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite. TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented communication, while UDP provides unreliable, connectionless communication. HTTP, DNS, and SMTP are application layer protocols that rely on the transport layer protocols (TCP or UDP) for end-to-end communication.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th ed.). Pearson.', 'Forouzan, B. A. (2021). TCP/IP Protocol Suite (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill Education.', 'IETF RFC 793 - Transmission Control Protocol. (1981). https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc793', 'IETF RFC 768 - User Datagram Protocol. (1980). https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc768']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet frame provides a method for the receiving Network Interface Card (NIC) to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors. The FCS is a 32-bit Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) value calculated by the sending device based on the frame contents. The receiving NIC recalculates the CRC and compares it with the FCS value in the frame. If they match, the frame is considered error-free; otherwise, the frame is discarded due to transmission errors.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs)', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet']
